metadata.title: N- and S- co-doped graphene sheet-encapsulated Co9S8 nanomaterials as excellent electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Power Sources
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/jpowsour
N- and S- co-doped graphene sheet-encapsulated Co9S8 nanomaterials as excellent electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction
Jiawen Zhonga, Tao Wua, Qian Wua, Shuo Dua,d, Dongchu Chenb,∗, Bo Chena, Menglei Changb, Xiaohu Luoa,c,∗∗, Yali Liua,∗∗∗
a State Key Laboratory for Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, Hunan, 410082, PR China b School of Material Science and Energy Engineering, Foshan University, Foshan, 528000, PR China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qiannan Normal University for Nationalities, Duyun, 558000, PR China d Key Laboratory of Materials Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (HUST), Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST), Wuhan, 430074, China
H I G H L I G H T S
• Polydiaminothiazole provides the N and S co-doped into the carbon. • Co9S8/NSG hybrid electrocatalyst was prepared by a facile pyrolysis method. • Overpotentials of 260mV at a current density of 10mA cm−2. • Low tafel slope of 55mV dec−1.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Oxygen evolution reaction Co9S8 nanoparticles Metal-organic frameworks Nitrogen Sulfur co-doped graphene
A B S T R A C T
The development of highly efficient and earth-abundant electrocatalysts to replace the rare and expensive noble metal catalysts is currently an important goal of renewable energy research. We report advanced and highly efficient electrocatalysis of oxygen evolution reaction using the cobalt sulfide (Co9S8) nanoparticles embedded in nitrogen, sulfur co-doped graphene (Co9S8/NSG) hybrid materials, which are obtained by coating Co-based metal-organic frameworks. The frameworks are grown in situ on graphene oxide using a facile pyrolysis method, with polydiaminothiazole, which serves as both a nitrogen and a sulfur source in the system. The prominent synergistic effect of the S, N-co-doped graphene helps to enhance the conductivity of the hybrid, and the Co9S8 provides abundant catalytic active sites as well as mesoporous structure. As a result, the Co9S8/NSG hybrid materials exhibit outstanding performance in the oxygen evolution reaction and superior stability in alkaline electrolytes. For example, the hybrid materials have a small overpotential of 0.26 V with a Tafel slope of 55mV dec−1 at a current density of 10mA cm−2 and they show long-term stability in 1M KOH. This work provides a general and promising method for the design and synthesis of inexpensive and efficient OER electrocatalysts.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2019.02.024 Received 13 December 2018; Received in revised form 23 January 2019; Accepted 7 February 2019
∗ Corresponding author. ∗∗ Corresponding author. State Key Laboratory for Chemo/Biosensing and Chemometrics, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University,
Changsha, Hunan, 410082, PR China. ∗∗∗ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: Chendc@fosu.edu.cn (D. Chen), luoxiaohu4812350@hnu.edu.cn (X. Luo), yaliliu@hnu.edu.cn (Y. Liu).
Journal of Power Sources 417 (2019) 90–98
0378-7753/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Electrochemical water splitting is a sustainable chemical processes that can generate carbon-free, high energy density hydrogen for the purpose of storing solar energy [1]. Water splitting contains two halfreactions, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [2]. The oxygen evolution reaction is a kinetically and thermodynamically sluggish process and it requires highly effective electrocatalysts to accelerate electrochemical process [3,4]. To date, the commercial state-of-the-art electrocatalysts for the OER are the noble metals, such as iridium and ruthenium oxides (RuO2 or IrO2) [5,6]. Despite their high efficiency, the practical large-scale use of noble metal as electrocatalysts is impeded by their high cost, inferior durability and low abundance [7–9]. Thus, it is very important to find suitable alternatives to RuO2 and IrO2 that are highly efficient for electrochemical water splitting, inexpensive, stable and earth-abundant materials.
Recently, transition metal chalcogenides, for example oxides [10–12], sulfides [13–16], and selenides [17], have been reported to be OER electrocatalysts with promising catalytic activity and earth abundance. However, transition metal chalcogenides are is still far from satisfactory due to their low electrical conductivity, instability, small specific surface area, and facile aggregation in electrolyte solutions [8,18,19]. Recently, the transition metal chalcogenides have been doped into conductive substrates, such as graphene and carbon nanotubes, particularly heteroatom doped to carbon materials (such as N [20–22], S [23,24], P [25,26], etc.). The graphene or nanotube carbon materials increase the conductivity of the transition metals and protect the active metal site from aggregation to improve stability [21,27]. Meanwhile, heteroatom-doped carbon exhibits excellent catalytic activity because the heteroatom is able to change the charge density and electronic structure of carbon materials to enhance catalytic activity [8,28–31]. For examples Zhong et al. found that Co9S8 nanoparticles grown in situ on N and S co-doped porous carbon hybrid materials were highly efficient OER electrocatalysts, with a low overpotential of 0.31 V at 10mA cm−2 and a small Tafel slope of 68mV dec−1 in basic solution [32]. In another example, Duo et al. demonstrated that Ndoped Co9S8/G (N-Co9S8/G), prepared by the NH3 plasma treatment method, exhibited an enhanced OER performance, with a small of 0.409 V at 10mA cm−2 in alkaline solution [33]. Recently, a series of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which have a high surface area, large pore volume, and tunable porous structure, have attracted the interest of researchers [23,34–37]. For example, Yilmaz et al. reported that a zeolite imidazolate framework (ZIF-67) could be used to fabricate the hybrid NiCo-LDH/Co9S8 system for HER catalysts and supercapacitor via in situ pseudomorphic transformations of the ZIF-67 hollow rhombic dodecahedron template and sulfurization of NiCoLDHss [38]. In another example, a ZIF-67 hollow Co9S8 embedded in graphitic carbon nanocages is synthesized via a top-down route as superior Li-ion storage by Liu and co-workers [39]. Previously, we successfully developed a porous Co9S8/N, S-doped carbon@Mo2C bifunctional electrocatalyst for the HER over the entire pH range and excellent OER performance in basic solution [40]. However, the process required to prepare these materials is complicated, the nanoparticles easily agglomerate, the specific surface area of the sample is small, and it is not possible to simultaneously dope in both nitrogen and sulfur atoms. Thus, synthesizing a highly active and stable electrocatalyst using an easy method is still a challenge.
Based on the above analysis, in this study, we design a facile route (Scheme 1) to prepare Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded in nitrogen, sulfur co-doped carbon hybrid materials (Co9S8/NSG). This simple method not only results in N and S co-doping into graphene-based materials but also converts the Co2+ species in Co-ZIF-67 to Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded in nitrogen, sulfur co-doped graphitic carbon. The resulting materials show high catalytic activity for the OER. The important results of this work are as follows: First, the N, S co-doped graphene (NSG) not only acts as a substrate to anchor the Co9S8
nanoparticles but also acts as a reactant and host for the inoculation of Co9S8, and it can significantly enhance the conductivity of the material speeding up electron transfer. Additionally, the NSG layers can prevent the agglomeration of the Co9S8 nanoparticles, enhancing the stability of the Co9S8/NSG hybrid materials. Second, the 2-aminothiazole (2-AT) has been chosen as the all-in-one N- and S containing precursor for synthesizing NSG. Third, the synergistic effect of the N- and S- doping in the graphene changes the charge density and electronic structure of the carbon materials and improves the conductivity of the transition metal oxide, enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, the Co9S8/NSG composite exhibited highly efficient catalytic activity and stability for the OER.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Natural graphite flakes (100 mesh) were purchased from SigmaAldrich. Sulfuric acid (H2SO4), potassium hydroxide (KOH), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), hydrochloric acid (HCl), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2≥30%), and ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co (NO3)2·6H2O), 2-aminothiazole (2-AT), 2-methylimidazole (2-MI), 1,4- dioxane, benzoperoxide (BPO), methanol (CH3OH), commercial RuO2, and Nafion (5 wt%) were purchased from Adamas Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used without further purification.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of graphite oxide
sections.text: The graphite oxide (GO) was prepared from natural graphite powder according to the modified Hummers method [41]. Briefly, 3.0 g of graphite powder was added into 69ml of concentrated sulfuric acid under stirring at a temperature below 20 °C, and 10.0 g of KMnO4 was slowly added to the suspension. The temperature of the reaction system was increased to 35 °C where it was maintained for 2 h, followed by the addition of 160mL of H2O. After 15min of stirring, an additional 400mL of H2O and 10ml of H2O2 was slowly added to the mixture. The suspension was washed with a 1:10 HCl solution to remove sulfate ions and metal ions; then, it was washed with H2O until the pH became neutral. The GO was obtained by freeze-drying.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of the metal-organic framework Co-ZIF-67
sections.text: Briefly, 0.656 g of 2-aminothiazole (2-mIM) and 0.582 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) were each added to 25mL of methanol to form two solutions. Then, the two solutions were mixed together and kept at room temperature for 12 h. Afterwards, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed with plenty of ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h [40].

sections.heading: 2.4. Synthesis of P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67
sections.text: One tenth of a gram of Co-ZIF-67 was dispersed in 50mL of 1,4- dioxane by sonication for 30min; then, 0.2 g of 2-aminothiazole (2-TA) and 0.488 g of benzoperoxide (BPO) were dissolved in the above solution under sonication. The homogeneous mixture was stirred vigorously at 80 °C under nitrogen with a reflux condenser for 4 h. A brown precipitate was obtained by centrifugation and washed with deionized water three times. The resulting P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67 was collected after freeze-drying [40].

sections.heading: 2.5. Synthesis of Co9S8/NSG
sections.text:
One hundred milligrams of GO was dispersed in 50mL of deionized water by ultrasonication for 1 h to form a homogeneous GO mixture. Then, 50mg of the as-obtained P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67 was added to the
above GO dispersion, followed by ultrasonication for approximately 1 h at room temperature to achieve a homogeneous suspension. The product was obtained by freeze-drying, resulting in a black powder. Then, the brown powders were placed on a quartz boat in a tube furnace and thermally treated at 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under an N2 atmosphere. To remove metallic species, the black powder was added to 50mL of a HCl (1mol L−1) solution for 6 h under strong agitation, washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h. This finally yielded the Nand S- co-doped graphene-encapsulated Co9S8 nanomaterial (Co9S8/ NSG). To study the impact of the calcination temperature on the catalytic performance, the P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67@GO was subjected to different annealing temperatures of 700, 800, 900, and 1000 °C. The resulting products are denoted as Co9S8/NSG–T (i.e., Co9S8/NSG-7, Co9S8/NSG-8, Co9S8/NSG-9, and Co9S8/NSG-10, respectively). For comparison, the as-synthesized P-2TA@Co-ZIF-67 was placed on a quartz boat in a tube furnace and thermally treated at 800 °C for 2 h at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 under an N2 atmosphere. The resulting material is denoted as Co9S8@NSC.

sections.heading: 2.6. Physical characterization
sections.text: The morphologies of the samples were characterized using emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100 Plus, Japan). The elemental compositions and the chemical states of the materials were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PHI 5700 ESCA, USA). The structural analyses of the materials were obtained using a Polycrystalline Powder X-ray Diffraction Analyser (XRD6100, Japan). The Raman spectra were collected on a Renishaw inVia Reflex Micro-Raman spectrometer (Renishaw, UK). The BrunauerEmmett-Teller surface and nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the materials were obtained using a Tri-Star 3020 analyser (USA).

sections.heading: 2.7. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The electrochemical measurements on the materials were performed using an electrochemical station (CHI660e, CH Instruments) in a three-electrode system. The saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and a platinum foil electrode were used as the reference electrode and the counter electrode, respectively. To prepare the electrocatalyst suspension, 4mg of the electrocatalyst was added to 1.9 mL of ethanol and 0.1 mL of Nafion solution (5 wt%) to form a homogeneous dispersion under sonication for 1 h. The glassy carbon working electrode was covered with 7 μL of the catalyst suspension (2mgmL−1, catalyst loading of 0.2mg cm−2) and dried in air. For the electrochemical measurements, a 1M KOH solution was used as the electrolyte. The linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curves of the catalyst were obtained by sweeping the potential from 0 to 0.8 V versus the SCE with a scan
rate of 5mV s−1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements of the catalyst were carried out at an overpotential of 260mV from 0.1 to 100 KHz with a 5mV sinusoidal perturbation. The Nyquist plot is assigned to charge-transfer resistance (Rct), which may reflect the electrocatalytic kinetics. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed in the potential region of 1.14–1.21 V vs. the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) at different scan rates, which can be performed to calculate the double layer capacitance (Cdl). The capacitance was obtained from the scan rate dependence of the charging current density (Δj) at E=1.17 V vs. the RHE, where the slope of Δj against the scan rate is proportional to the double layer capacitance (Cdl). The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) is assumed to be proportional to the Cdl. The accelerated durability test used cyclic voltammetry by potential cycling between 0 and 0.8 V versus SCE at a sweep rate of 100mV s−1 for a given number of cycles. All the SCE electrode potentials were converted into the potentials versus the RHE using the Nernst equation: Evs (RHE)= Evs (SCE) + Eo (SCE) + 0.059 pH. All measured polarization curves were obtained with iR compensation (95%).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The synthesis of Co9S8/NSG is illustrated in Scheme 1. First, Co-ZIF67 dodecahedral nanoparticles are fabricated by the coordination reaction between the Co ion and 2-mIM in methanol solution via a simple deposition approach at room temperature. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Co-ZIF-67 show a uniform dodecahedral shape with an average particle size of ∼700 nm (Fig. S1a, b). Subsequently, P-2AT, which provides a source of S and N, was coated on the as-prepared Co-ZIF-67 nanoparticle using the polymerization of 2-AT. The successful polymerization of 2-AT was observed by the appearance of the broad N-H band (3300 cm−1) of P-2AT and the shift of the C=N band (1642-1603 cm−1) in the Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) (Fig. 1) [32]. After successfully coating the Co-ZIF-67 nanoparticles, the P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67 nanoparticle retains the morphology and structure of Co-ZIF-67 but shows a smooth surface compared to the as-isolated precursor (Figs. S1c and d). The P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67 nanoparticles were subsequently dispersed in a GO suspension by ultrasonication for 2 h at room temperature to form a homogeneous dispersion before freeze-drying to obtain GO@P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67. Subsequently, the GO@P-2AT@Co-ZIF-67 precursor was converted into the electrocatalyst, Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded in N, S co-doped graphene (Co9S8/NSG), by direct thermal treatment.
SEM and TEM images of the Co9S8/NSG hybrid material are shown in Fig. 2. Compared to the Co9S8@NSC nanoparticles (Fig. S2), after doping the graphene oxide (GO) (Fig. S3), large amounts of Co9S8 nanoparticles are uniformly embedded in the graphene (RGO). The graphene carbon matrix not only acts as a substrate to anchor the Co9S8 nanoparticles but also is a reactant and host for the inoculation of
Scheme 1. Illustration of the preparation of the Co9S8/NSG.
Co9S8. The HR-TEM image of Co9S8/NSG (Fig. 2c) clearly exhibits layers with two distinct phases, a black region of Co9S8 nanoparticles and a grey region of RGO around the edges of the Co9S8, which show a typical core-layer structure. The interplanar distance of 0.298 nm corresponds to the (311) planes of the cubic Co9S8 phase. The HAADFSTEM images of the Co9S8/NSG hybrid material show that the Co9S8 nanoparticles are uniformly distributed in the graphene (RGO) (Fig. 2d). The corresponding elemental mapping images show the presence of C, N, O, Co, S, and Co/S (Fig. 2e–j). The C, N, and O elements are uniformly distributed across the whole area. The Co and S elements primarily exist on the ZIF-67 skeleton, but the S is partially distributed across the entire RGO layer, indicating S-doping into the graphene sheet structure. The presence of the O atoms in the materials may be attributed to absorbed oxygen species or to the presence of oxygen-containing groups in the graphene, as has been reported previously [2].
The crystalline phases of the materials were further investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD). All the diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern of Co-ZIF-67 agreed well with previous reports and simulations [42,43]. The characteristic diffraction peaks of the P-2AT@CoZIF-67 material agreed well with Co-ZIF-67 (Fig. S4), suggesting that the polymerization of 2-AT does not change the crystallinity of the Co-ZIF-67 (Fig. S4). The XRD patterns are shown in Fig. S3. The main diffraction peaks of the Co9S8/NSG nanoparticles at 2θ of 15.4°, 29.8°, 31.2°, 39.5°, 47.6°, 52.1°, 61.2°, 62.0°, 73.2°, and 76.7° that can be assigned to the (111), (311), (222), (331), (511), (440), (533), (622), (731), and (800) lattice planes of Co9S8 phase (PDF#65-6801), respectively. No diffraction peaks associated with Co metal species were observed, while a peak at 26° can be indexed to the (002) plane of RGO. The XRD patterns also agree with the HRTEM image. We further investigated the effect of the pyrolysis temperature on the crystalline phases. As seen in Fig. S5, the diffraction peaks of the materials are consistent with phase-pure Co9S8 (PDF#65-6801) at different pyrolysis temperatures. It is clear that the XRD peaks of the samples synthesized using lower or higher temperatures (700 or 1000 °C) are relatively weak compared to those of Co9S8/ NSG-8; this may indicate that a low temperature is not conducive to the formation of the Co9S8 crystal phase, and a higher pyrolysis temperature may destroy the crystal structure of the Co9S8 nanoparticles. The diffraction peaks of Co9S8/NSG-8 agree well with the JCPDS card 65- 6801, which suggests the successful conversion of the Co2+ species in P-2AT@CoZIF-67 to Co9S8 at a temperature of 800 °C in N2 (see Fig. 3).
Raman spectroscopy was further used to investigate the degree of graphitization and the defect level of the carbon material. Two Raman peaks at 1350 and 1580 cm−1 can be attributed to the D band of defects or disordered structures and the graphitic G band [44,45], respectively. The intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (ID/IG) can reveal the
amount of defects in carbon materials [45]. As shown in Fig. 4a, the weakest peak at 662 cm−1 in the Raman spectrum of Co9S8/NSG was assigned to Co9S8. Clearly, the ID/IG ratio of the Co9S8/NSG-T materials decreased from 0.962 to 0.859 when the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 700 to 1000 °C. This indicates that the highest pyrolysis temperature leads to the lowest degree of defects and that more graphitization structure in the material. The ID/IG ratio of Co9S8/NSG-800 (0.926) was higher than that of RGO (0.807), which means the N-, Sdopted in graphene (RGO) have to destroy the graphitization structure and form more defects.
The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas were investigated using N2 adsorption/desorption measurements. As shown in Fig. 4b, the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms at 77 K of Co9S8/NSG-8 resembles as typical Ⅳ isotherms with distinct hysteresis loops at a relative pressure ranging from 0.45 to 1.0, indicating the presence of a distinct mesoporous microstructure with a BET specific surface area of 74.48m2 g−1. This value is higher than that of Co9S8@NSC (72.91 m2 g−1) but lower than those of Co9S8/NSG-7 (76.33 m2 g−1), Co9S8/NSG-9 (164.01m2 g−1), and Co9S8/NSG-10 (95.91 m2 g−1). Compared to the control samples, the lower specific surface area of Co9S8/NSG-8 may be due to a reaction between S atoms and the Co atoms in the Co-based MOFs to form Co-S bonds that partially covers the pores. The mesoporous structures of Co9S8/NSG hybrid materials are thought to contribute to their large surface areas and favourable pore volumes, resulting in catalytic active site exposure and improved mass transport [46–48].
The chemical structures and surface chemical states of Co9S8/NSG-8 were further investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. S6, Co9S8/NSG-8 exhibits main peaks signals at 165.4, 284.7, 400.0, 532.5, and 781.3 eV that can be assigned to S 2p, C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and Co 2p, respectively. The presence of O atoms in the material may be attributed to absorbed oxygen species or to oxygencontaining groups present in the graphene. Quantitative analysis of the Co9S8/NSG-T materials obtained from different pyrolysis temperatures and Co9S8/NSC indicates that the Co/S molar ratios in the Co9S8/NSG-T materials are lower than the theoretical value of 9/8 (Table S1), which reveals that S atoms, in addition to those incorporated to form Co9S8, are incorporated into the RGO sheet during the calcination process. This result is consistent with the elemental mapping (Fig. 2). However, the Co/S molar ratio of Co9S8@NSC is higher than 9/8, which again shows that additional Co atoms are present in Co9S8@NSC materials. This is consistent with the results obtained from the XRD analysis (Fig. S7). The high-resolution XPS spectra for the C 1s of Co9S8/NSG are shown in Fig. 5a. The spectra was divided into five peaks, corresponding to C=C-C (284.7 eV), C-N/C-S (285.6 eV), C-O (286.6 eV), C=O (288.1 eV) and O-C=O (289.9 eV) species. The peak associated with the C-N and C-S moieties is due to the substitution of C atoms with N and S atoms in Co9S8/NSG-8, demonstrating the co-doping of S and N into the carbon matrix. The peaks corresponding to C-O and C=O are indicative of the presence of –C-OOH and –C-OH species in the material. In the N 1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 5b), the N 1s peak was deconvoluted into four peaks, which are pyridinic N (396.2 eV), pyrrolic N (397.7 eV), quaternary N (400.1 eV), and oxidized N (403.8 eV) species [49]. It is notable that, in the XPS spectra of Co9S8/NSG-T, the pyridinic-N peak only occurs in Co9S8/NSG-8 when the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 700 to 1000 °C (Fig. S8b and Table S2). It has been widely reported that pyridinic-N acts on the active site to improve the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst [33]. Thus, in the case of Co9S8/ NSG, the presence of pyridinic-N groups with a total content of 10.6% contributed positively to the OER performance. In the S 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5c and Fig. S8d), five peaks corresponding to different sulfur species were observed. The peaks at 161.2 eV and 162.8 eV, with an energy split value of 1.6 eV, can be attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively, of Co9S8. The peak at 163.8 eV in the spectra was attributed to the C-S-C, and the peaks at 167.6 eV and 169.1 eV were assigned to SO42− species. The presence of C-S-C in the sulfur spectra shows that
S atoms were doped into the lattice of the graphene matrix successfully, in addition to forming the graphene carbon encapsulated Co9S8 nanoparticles. The presence of SO42− indicates the existence of some sulfate or sulfite moieties on the materials due to the possible partial oxidation of S [50]. Compared to Co9S8/NSG-8, the percentage contents of the CoS peak in Co9S8@NSC decreased (Fig. S9d and Table S4). This indicates that the degree of crystallization of Co9S8@NSC is low, so more Co atoms exist as a simple substance; thus, the RGO sheet substrate promotes the formation of Co-S bonds, improving the crystallinity of Co9S8.
In the high-resolution XPS spectra of the Co 2p (Fig. 5d), the Co 2p spectra were deconvoluted into eight peaks, including two pairs of spinorbit doubles and four shakeup satellite peaks (denoted “sat”). The binding energies observed at 777.6 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 793.6 eV for Co 2p1/2 arise from the spin-orbit characteristics of Co3+, whereas the peaks centred at 780.3 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 796.2 eV for Co 2p1/2 originate from the spin-orbit characteristics of Co2+, demonstrating the presence of Co9S8 in the graphene carbon support. As shown in Figs. S8c and S9c and Table S4, Co9S8/NSG-8 has the highest Co3+ content
amongst the Co9S8@NSC and Co9S8/NSG-T materials. In this study, the Co3+ species are expected to enhance the electrocatalytic activity for the OER.

sections.heading: 3.1. Electrochemical performance
sections.text:
The OER electrocatalytic activities of the as-synthesized materials and materials prepared using different pyrolysis temperatures were then investigated. The electrocatalytic properties of the materials were measured using a three-electrode system in a 1M KOH solution. In the system, a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with a homogeneous loading of 0.2 mg cm−2 of catalyst was used as the working electrode, a platinum wire was used as the counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was used as the reference electrode. For comparison, similar measurements were carried out on Co9S8@NSC nanoparticles, the Co9S8/NSG-T materials, and commercial RuO2 under the same conditions. As seen in Fig. 6a–b, the overpotentials at a current density of 10mA cm−2, which is the current density expected for a 10% efficient solar fuel synthesis, are 210, 360, 260, 28, 300, and 440mV for RuO2, Co9S8/NSG-7, Co9S8/NSG-8, Co9S8/NSG-9, Co9S8/NSG-10, and Co9S8@ NSC, respectively. Apparently, the Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded in the N, S co-doped graphene electrocatalysts (Co9S8/NSG-T) produce a current density of 10mA cm−2 at the overpotential, which is much lower than that of Co9S8@NSC and other control samples (Fig. S10). This reveals their excellent OER catalytic activities. Compared to Co9S8@NSC, the N, S co-doped RGO Co9S8 nanoparticle materials (Co9S8/NSG) have high catalytic activity for the OER in basic media, most likely due to a synergistic effect between the Co9S8 nanoparticles and the N, S co-doped NSG. The presence of the graphene (RGO) sheet in the Co9S8/NSG-T materials may improve the electrical conductivity
of the materials and facilitate electron transport [29]. Additionally, Nand S- co-doped graphene changes the charge density and electronic structure of carbon materials and improve the conductivity of the transition metal oxide to enhance catalytic activity [51,52]. The RGO sheet also protects the Co9S8 nanoparticles to avoid loss, resulting in their outstanding catalytic stability in basic media. To further investigate the influence of the calcination temperature on the OER catalytic performance, Fig. 6a–b shows the polarization curves of Co9S8/ NSG-T with different pyrolysis temperatures. The Co9S8/NSG-7 and Co9S8/NSG-10 materials show overpotentials of 300mV and 360mV, respectively at a current density of 10mA cm−2. Compared to Co9S8/ NSG-7 and Co9S8/NSG-10, Co9S8/NSG-9 shows a lower overpotential of 280mV at a current density of 10mA cm−2, and Co9S8/NSG-8 has the smallest overpotential of 260mV at a current density of 10mA cm−2. These results may be due to reduced crystallinity of the Co9S8 crystal phase and the reduced amounts of pyridinic-N and Co3+ species (Table S2 and Table S3) at the lower or higher pyrolysis temperatures. Some recent studies have reported that pyridinic-N and Co3+ species are effective active sites for the OER [52,53].
To explore the OER kinetics of the electrocatalysts, Tafel plots (log j vs. η) were obtained from the corresponding OER linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves. The Tafel plots were fitted to the Tafel equation (η = a + b × log j, where η is the overpotential, j is the current density, b is the Tafel slope, and a is a constant). The Tafel slope of Co9S8/NSG-8 is 55 mV dec−1, which is much smaller than those of the control materials, Co9S8/NSG-7 (107.5 mV dec−1), Co9S8/NSG-9 (79mV dec−1), Co9S8/NSG-10 (82mV dec−1), and Co9S8@NSC (187.7 mV dec−1) (Fig. 6c), implying that Co9S8/NSG-8 has faster intrinsic OER catalytic kinetics. The small overpotential and the low Tafel slope value show that the Co9S8/NSG-8 hybrid catalyst shows excellent electrocatalytic activity for the OER. Additionally, the Tafel slope of Co9S8/NSG-8 (55mV dec−1) is much lower than those of the Co9S8/ NSG-T materials (107.5, 79, and 82mV dec−1 for Co9S8/NSG-7, Co9S8/ NSG-9, and Co9S8/NSG-10, respectively) and of Co9S8@NSC (Fig. 6c). This shows that the Co9S8/NSG-8 hybrid catalyst show excellent intrinsic OER kinetics. In addition, these favourable kinetics were investigated using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The EIS results are shown in Fig. 6d. The charge-transfer resistance (Rct) reflects the electrocatalytic kinetics at the electrolyte and electrocatalyst interface, and a lower value suggests more rapid electron transfer [53]. Co9S8/NSG-8 has a lower Rct value (49.5Ω) compared to the other materials (Co9S8/NSG-7 (90.9Ω), Co9S8/NSG-9 (64.9Ω), Co9S8/NSG-10 (79.3Ω), and Co9S8@NSC (119.7Ω). This shows that Co9S8/NSG-8 has rapid electron transfer and favourable OER kinetics at the electrocatalyst/electrolyte interface. The EIS results agree well with the OER LSV measurements. The Co9S8/NSG-8 hybrid electrocatalyst was compared with recently reported Co-based catalysts, as shown in Table S6. It is noteworthy that Co9S8/NSG-8 is highly competitive due to its unique and superior structural features.
The stability of the electrocatalyst is also an important property for
an OER electrocatalyst in practical applications. Hence, the long-term durability of Co9S8/NSG-8 was determined from the current-time curves of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) over 10 h at a current density of 10mV cm−2 (Fig. 6e). The results show that Co9S8/NSG-8 has outstanding stability (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, the stability of Co9S8/ NSG-8 was evaluated by continuous cycling CVs from 1.0 V to 1.8 V vs. RHE for 2000 cycles at a constant scan rate of 50mV s−1 in a 1M KOH solution. As seen in Fig. 6f, after 2000 cycles, the OER polarization curves of Co9S8/NSG show a slight shift. This result reveals good stability for Co9S8/NSG under basic conditions.
To further elucidate the strongly enhanced OER performance of the Co9S8/NSG-8 hybrid catalyst, we investigated the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl), which is proportional to the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA), effectively reflecting the number of active sites for the OER. The results are shown in Figs. S11a–c. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out on Co9S8/NSG-8 in the nonfaradaic region from 1.14 to 1.21 V vs. RHE at different scan rates (20–200mV s−1), which were performed to calculate the double layer capacitance. The capacitance was obtained from the scan rate dependence of the charging current density (Δj) at E=1.17 V vs. RHE, where the slope of Δj against the scan rate is proportional to the Cdl. The Cdl value for Co9S8/NSG-8 is approximately 26.5mF cm−2, which is much higher than that of Co9S8@NSC (11.5mF cm−2). The large Cdl (i.e., ECSA) can indicate better exposure and enhanced utilization of the catalytic active sites, thus giving rise to an enhanced electrocatalytic active site density. Additionally, the Faradaic efficiency during the OER was determined. The results are shown in Fig. S11d. The measured amount of O2 produced over a period of 60min is almost the same as the theoretical value based on the charge consumed.
From the above experimental results, we can conclude that the Co9S8/NSG hybrid catalysts have excellent OER activities. It is well
known that the surface chemical composition and the chemical state of the elements in the electrocatalyst play very significant roles in the OER process. Thus, XPS measurements on Co9S8/NSG before and after the stability test were further carried out to probe the origin of the enhanced effect on the OER electrocatalytic performance. The C 1s, N 1s, and S 2p spectra (Figs. S12a–c) after the stability measurements have no obvious charges compared to before the measurements. In the Co 2p spectra (Fig. S13a), the peak positions of the Co 2p shift to lower binding energies compared to the initial species, suggesting that the surface Co2+ was oxidized after the continuous electrochemical measurements [2]. This is further demonstrated by the change in the Co3+ species during the OER process. After the stability tests, the intensities of the Co3+ peaks are stronger than before the tests, indicating an increased amount of Co3+, which results from the oxidization of Co2+ (Table S5). For the O 1s spectra (Fig. S13b), three peaks after the stability tests. The peaks located at 531.2 and 532.4 eV can be assigned to the metal-O band (O1) and to C=O [54], respectively. The peak centred at 433.2 eV arises from O-H groups. The existence of metal-O peaks further suggest the surface partial oxidation of Co. Based on the XPS analyses, increased amounts of Co3+ species are formed during the OER process. Recently, researchers have shown that for Co-based electrocatalysts, the main reactive sites are active metal hydroxide/ (oxy)-hydroxide species [55–57], and the Co3+ is capable of promoting the formation of these active species [40,58].
Based on the above experimental results, the excellent OER activity of Co9S8/NSG catalysts can be explained as follows: (1) the inherently catalytically active Co9S8 nanoparticles may play a synergistic role in the electrochemical OER in an alkaline solution due to the advantages of the distinctive nanointerfaces that result from the heteroatom-doped graphitic carbon shell, which provides a core-shell architecture [1]. This unique architecture not only provides the combined properties of
the two different materials but also generates synergistic effects, which are favourable for catalytic processes. (2) N, S-co-doping in carbonbased materials, regardless of whether the dopants have higher or lower electronegativity compared to carbon, affects the electron neutrality of the carbon and induces charge redistribution. This may enhance the adsorption of intermediates (i.e., HO*, O*, and HOO*) on the surface of the electrocatalyst and possibly decreases the binding energy between the intermediates and the catalyst surface [52,59,60]. (3) The carbon layers coated in Co9S8 nanoparticles not only enhance the conductivity of the electrocatalyst, facilitating electron transfer, but also effectively
prevent the dissolution and aggregation of the Co9S8 nanoparticles during the OER process [1]. (4) The mesoporous structure, with its higher specific surface area, not only offers more active sites but also improves the electrolyte transfer during the OER process [61]. Thus, all these factors synergistically enable the outstanding electrocatalytic activity and stability of the Co9S8/NSG catalysts for the OER.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, electrocatalysts with Co9S8 nanoparticles embedded in
N, S co-doped graphene (Co9S8/NSG) with hierarchical porous architectures have been successfully prepared by a facile pyrolysis method. In particular, the novel hybrid Co9S8/NSG has been found to be a remarkable electrocatalyst for the OER in alkaline solutions, with a low overpotential of 260mV and a small Tafel slope of 55mV dec−1 at a current density of 10mA cm−2. The excellent electrocatalytic activity towards the OER exhibited by Co9S8/NSG can be attributed to synergetic effects between the N, S co-doped graphitic carbon and Co9S8 nanoparticles in the materials. This report provides a new application for metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with an attractive structure for energy conversion applications.

referenceMentions.context: Electrochemical water splitting is a sustainable chemical processes that can generate carbon-free, high energy density hydrogen for the purpose of storing solar energy [1].
Water splitting contains two halfreactions, the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [2].
The oxygen evolution reaction is a kinetically and thermodynamically sluggish process and it requires highly effective electrocatalysts to accelerate electrochemical process [3,4].
The oxygen evolution reaction is a kinetically and thermodynamically sluggish process and it requires highly effective electrocatalysts to accelerate electrochemical process [3,4].
To date, the commercial state-of-the-art electrocatalysts for the OER are the noble metals, such as iridium and ruthenium oxides (RuO2 or IrO2) [5,6].
